stress: You're carrying a lot right now — that heaviness is important to notice and treat kindly.
It makes sense to feel tense when things pile up — your body's reacting to pressure.
sadness: I'm really sorry you're feeling this. Sadness can be so heavy.
It's okay to slow down — rest is often the most compassionate move when sorrow is present.

stress_intervention.step1_text: You sound stressed. Would you like a short grounding routine, help to prioritize tasks, or a paced breathing exercise?

openers: I hear you — that sounds important.
closers: Remember to be kind to yourself.

fallbacks.positive: That sounds like a positive moment — thanks for sharing it.
fallbacks.negative: It sounds like a heavy moment — thank you for opening up about it.
fallbacks.neutral: I see. Could you tell me a little more about what's on your mind?

box_breathing.title: Box Breathing
steps: Inhale slowly for 4 counts.
Hold for 4 counts.
Exhale gently for 4 counts.
Hold for 4 counts.
box_breathing.evidence: Used by Navy SEALs and clinicians to regulate stress.

double_exhale.title: Double Exhale Breathing
steps: Inhale gently through your nose for 4 counts.
Exhale slowly through your mouth for 8 counts.
Repeat this cycle for 5 breaths.
double_exhale.evidence: Extended exhalation boosts vagal tone, calming the nervous system.

478_breathing.title: 4-7-8 Breathing
steps: Inhale through the nose for 4 counts.
Hold the breath for 7 counts.
Exhale slowly through the mouth for 8 counts.
Repeat 4 times.
478_breathing.evidence: Developed by Dr. Andrew Weil; reduces anxiety and aids sleep.

diaphragmatic_breathing.title: Diaphragmatic Breathing
steps: Place one hand on your chest and one on your belly.
Inhale deeply so your belly rises while your chest stays still.
Exhale slowly and fully.
Repeat for 5–10 breaths.

alternate_nostril.title: Alternate Nostril Breathing
steps: Close your right nostril with your thumb and inhale through your left nostril.
Close your left nostril with your finger, release the right, and exhale through the right nostril.
Inhale through the right nostril, close it, and exhale through the left.
Repeat for 5 cycles.
alternate_nostril.evidence: Balances autonomic nervous system and improves focus.

grounding_5_senses.title: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
steps: Notice 5 things you can see.
Notice 4 things you can touch.
Notice 3 things you can hear.
Notice 2 things you can smell.
Notice 1 thing you can taste.
grounding_5_senses.evidence: Common CBT technique for panic and trauma grounding.

body_scan.title: Body Scan Mindfulness
steps: Close your eyes and bring attention to your forehead.
Notice any tension, breathe into it, then let it go.
Move attention down through your shoulders, chest, arms, and legs.
End with noticing your whole body at rest.

thought_defusion.title: Thought Defusion
steps: Notice a troubling thought.
Imagine placing it on a cloud or leaf floating downstream.
Let it drift by without engaging with it.
Bring focus back to the present moment.

three_good_things.title: 3 Good Things
steps: Think of 3 good things that happened today.
Write them down or say them aloud.
Reflect on why they matter.
three_good_things.evidence: Positive psychology practice that boosts well-being.

pmr.title: Progressive Muscle Relaxation
steps: Tense your forehead for 5 seconds, then release.
Tense your shoulders for 5 seconds, then release.
Work down your arms, chest, legs, releasing each group.
Notice relaxation spreading.

tension_release_breath.title: Tension Release Breath
steps: Inhale deeply and tense all muscles for 5 seconds.
Exhale forcefully, releasing tension.
Repeat 3 times.
tension_release_breath.evidence: Quick reset for stress and anger.

shoulder_drop.title: Shoulder Drop
steps: Lift shoulders towards ears while inhaling.
Hold for 2 seconds.
Exhale and drop shoulders completely.
Repeat 3–5 times.
shoulder_drop.evidence: Relieves neck and upper back tension.

self_compassion_break.title: Self-Compassion Break
steps: Say: 'This is a moment of suffering.'
Say: 'Suffering is part of being human.'
Place a hand on your heart: 'May I be kind to myself.'
self_compassion_break.evidence: Dr. Kristin Neff’s work — reduces self-criticism.

safe_place.title: Safe Place Visualization
steps: Close your eyes and imagine a place where you feel safe and calm.
Notice the colors, sounds, and sensations.
Stay in this scene for 1–2 minutes.
safe_place.evidence: Used in trauma therapy to promote safety.

affirmation_reframing.title: Affirmation Reframing
steps: Notice a negative thought (e.g., 'I’m not good enough').
Gently replace it with a balanced one (e.g., 'I’m learning and growing').
Repeat the new thought 3 times.

journaling_prompt.title: Reflective Journaling
steps: Write down: 'What emotion am I feeling most strongly right now?'
Then: 'What triggered it?'
End with: 'What’s one small step I can take?'
